002.answer_rev1: This study found no adverse effect on B. terrestris dalmatinus of OSR treated with Elado seed dressing (Clothianidin and beta-cyfluthrin). No difference in hive weight, or numbers of workers produced were observed. No effect on numbers of young queens produced were observed in the post-exposure phase. Under field-realistic conditions used here clothianidin residue aws lower than often suggested by other studies (max 1.3ug/kg in pollen). This has clear importance for agrigultural practices and regulatory bodies and implies that when used as a seed dressing, the risk of some neonicotinoids may be low to bumblebees. This type of testing could be added to regulatory risk assessments.

005.answer_rev1:
This study found that the residues of thiamethoxam and its primary metabolite in pollen and nectar collected by bees foraging exclusively on crops that had been treated with a thiamethoxam seed dressing are typically low. Residues found in hive products were consistently even lower than that observed in pollen and nectar, indicating dilution or degradation. There is also nomcarry over from the same pesticide treatment used in two subsequent crop rotations. Over the four year study tehre was no observable diffrence between experimental and control hives in any of the measures monitored. 

Overall no detrimental effects of field-realistic exposure to pollen and nectar from the crops that received a seed treatment of thiamethoxam were observed, indicating a low-risk to foraging honeybees.

006.answer_rev2:
This study looks at the effects of sub-lethal exposure to five insecticides, using doses that are similar to background residual measures found in bee hives (in pollen and wax), on bee walking locomotion. Apart from fipronil, sub-lethal exposure to all the insecticides triggered serious locomotor deficits and reduced the distance covered by newly emerged bees. 

This is the first published identification of a reduction in walking in young bees after sub-lethal thiamethoxam exposure. 

Fipronil had no effect on bee locomotion at the sub-lethal dose applied. However, it was the only insecticide tested here that was associated with significant mortality at 5 days post-exposure.

Tau-fluvalinate is used as an in-hive treatment for the Varroa mite, but here it is observed to neagtively effect newly emerged bees, challenging its safety in this regard.

The effects to locomotion observed were insecticide-specific and could not be extrapoloated from published LD50 values.

From an agricultural or ecosystem point of view the banning of neonicotinoids has meant a rise in the use of pyrethroids which appear to be as toxic to bees in some cases. It is suggested that this standardised locomotion test be used in preliminary analyses of insecticides.

007.answer_rev2: This paper observed that the probiotic treatment of honeybees with Pediococcus acidilactici (PA) was efficient at protecting against N. ceranae infection, without disturbing the natural balance of the bee gut microbiome. N. ceranae infection is associated with increased sucrose consumption, something that is also lowered with PA treatment, indicating the lowering of the energetic cost of parasite load. PA treatment also restored the expression levels of the host-genes monitored by the study to a level similar to those observed in the control groups of bees. Probiotic treatment with PA of pesticide exposed bees completely restored survival rates to non-exposure levels. The level of expression of host-genes altered by pesticide exposure were also restored to non-exposure levels. PA may represent a natural tool to protect honeybees from both N. ceranae infection and pesticide exposure.

The paper finds that the methods used in bioassay 1 produced 100% mortality, with bees being damaged in the plastic collection pots. Bioassay 2 methodology was also inferior to bioassay 3 as there was >90% control mortality after 12 hours (probably due to the time spent in the freezer and damage to bees from the transfer from collection pots into experimental flasks). Therefore bioassy 3 was flagged as being the appropriate one to use.

Chlorantraniliprole aws found to be less toxic to T. travancorica than thiamethoxam. T. travancorica was also found to more sensitive to thiamethoxam than A. mellifera. Bees from the feral colony (no previous insecticide exposure) were more suscepible to thiamethoxam than bees from the vegetable ecostsyem colony (with regular potential insecticide exposure). This new bioassay method (bioassay 3) may help ecotoxicological assessments of T. travancorica.

009.answer_rev1:
This study is the first to report on the toxicity of  spinosad to P. lucii. It found that spinosad is as toxic as imidacloprid to the species. This is important as P. lucii colonies are made up of fewer workers than those of other eusocial bees, making the loss of workers more significant in terms of colony-success. P. lucii is a very small bee (length 3mm) and is more at risk from pesticides, not only directly because of their size, but also beacuse a small body size limits their flight range and foraging area, making them remain in pesticide treated areas rather than moving away. 

Walking and flight behaviours were negative effected by spinosad exposure, but no effect on body mass or respiration was observed. 

Overall this species interaction with pesticides deserves attention to ensure its conservation and the health of its ecosystem.

010.answer_rev2:
This study confirms that aversive training is a highly effective paradigm in sub-lethal pesticide trials. Sub-lethal concentrations of thiacloprid and sulfoxaflor did not effect the bees ability to respond to aversive training (reducing distance travellled to  reward) and were not associated with hyperactive behaviours. Bees treated with thiamethoxam however, did not develop an efficient route to the reward. This implies that sub-lethal treatment with thiamethoxam effects spatial learning and memory, which could impact foraging efficiency. They also increased their post-tarining speeds, implying hyperactivity. 

Sub-lethal sulfloxaflor exposure was not found to effect any of the parameters measured, making it a good candidate to replace neonicotinoids. This paper also suggests that power law analyses might be a useful tool in detecting sub-lethal effects and could be applied to current assessment tools.

011.answer_llm: The paper underscores the importance of vitellogenin in honey bee physiology, particularly its role in hormone signaling, stress management, and the transition from nurse bees to foragers. It suggests that altered vitellogenin levels due to pesticide exposure could have significant physiological consequences, warranting further research to validate its potential as a biomarker for pesticide exposure, which is vital for understanding and mitigating the effects of environmental stressors on bee populations.
011.answer_rev1:
This study confirmed that exposure to clothianidin leads to the increased production of vitellogenin protein (not simply increased RNA transcription). There was a 3-fold induction of full-length vitellogenin (180k-Da) in the fat body and significant increased production of lighter (150-kDa) vitellogenin in the brain. This lighter vitellogenein is not found in the brain of unexposed bees. The lighter version is proposed to be a cleaved (processed) form of the protein, perhaps associated with larval feeding by nurse bees (and might be used as a marker for nurse bees). Clothianidin led to differential induction of vitellogenin protein in different tissues.

Forager bees normally have lower vitellogenin levels than nurse bees, but exposure of foragers to clothianidin induced a nurse-bee-like phenotype. This could have significant physiological consequences for worker bees, as vitellogenin is involved in stress management, protection against oxidative stress and life-span.

The devlopment of the antibody used in this study can be used to analyse the effects of other pesticides on vitellogenin expression and function.

016.answer_rev2: This study demonstrates that sub-lethal doses of neonicotinoids can significantly alter honey bee flight ability, affecting distance, duration and velocity. At the actute dose (1.34ng/bee) flight distance and duration are significantly increased (>70%), which could impact the bees ability to return to the colony after foraging. After chronic level of exposure, in the range of 1.96-2.90ng/bee/day, the flight distance of bees was reduced significantly by 56%. This could lead to a decline in the area a bee uses for foraging, which could impact the pollination services provided by a colony and also impact its nutrition, by limiting the diversity of pollen collected. This work was the first to demonstrate that sub-lethal exposure to neonicotinoids can impact healthy colonies (ie not infested with Varroa mites).

052.answer_rev1: The study demonstrates that Apis cerana exhibits lower sensitivity to thiacloprid compared to imidacloprid. Thiacloprid exposure did not impair sucrose responsiveness or phototaxis climbing ability. However, learning and memory abilities were significantly impaired, especially under chronic exposure. Short-term exposure stimulated detoxification enzymes, including P450 monooxygenases and CarE, whereas chronic exposure suppressed CarE activity. Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity remained unchanged after both acute and chronic treatments. Transcriptomic analysis revealed consistent upregulation of immune- and stress-related genes following thiacloprid exposure. The authors also emphasize that chronic exposure to thiacloprid produces more severe toxic effects than acute exposure.

053.answer_rev1: The study found that deltamethrin was the most toxic and acetamiprid the least toxic to honey bee larvae (acute toxicity: deltamethrin > cypermethrin > carbaryl > acetamiprid). Carbaryl, acetamiprid and cypermethrin were more toxic to adults than larvae, while deltamethrin was more toxic to larvae. Chronic exposure reduced larval survival at high concentrations but not at field-relevant levels. Just chronic exposure to acetamiprid significantly affected larval weight. The NOAECs for all insecticides were well above residue levels found in pollen and nectar, and risk quotients were below levels of concern.

056.answer_rev1: The main findings of the study are that fipronil, acetamiprid, and chlorfenapyr exhibited similar rapid toxic effects after 30 minutes of contact, whereas ivermectin acted more slowly. Based on the mass content of active substances in the formulations, the acute contact toxicity to bees decreased in the following order: fipronil > ivermectin > chlorfenapyr > acetamiprid. Despite these differences, all baits were considered practically non-toxic to bees, as their LD50 values exceeded 100 μg/bee.

421.answer_rev1: The paper finds that exposure to field-realistic concentrations of thiacloprid can impact the immunocompetence of Osmia bicornis, potentially affecting their ability to mount a rapid immune response and their capacity to resist disease. Males exposed to concentrations above 200 ug/kg showed a reduction in hemocyte density and an impairement in the antimicrobial activity of the hemolymph. Immunosuppressive effects were only observed in females at concentrations of 555 ug/kg. This may be explained by the fact that males consumed more of the spiked sucrose solution, leading to a 2.77 times higher exposure compared to females. Exposure to thiacloprid did not affect the melanisation or wound healing response in either sex. Since only food consumption of females is typically considered in regulatory risk assessments, these results suggest that males should also be included in future risk assessment schemes for the approval and authorisation of pesticide use. The authors also emphasise the importance of studying non-Apis bees since they may respond differently and yet are still important contributers to crop and wild plant pollination.

422.answer_rev1: The study found that exposure to thiacloprid changed antennal responses to specific flower VOCs and alarm pheromones, and that these effects differed over the short and long term, with effects of pesticide exposure being more prominent in the short term, suggesting effects do not persist across generations. In the short term, thiacloprid exposure increased responses to the floral VOCs benzyl-alcohol and 1-hexanol, which are also found in honeybee sting gland secretions. Responses to QMP and alarm pheromone 2-heptanone were also affected. The response signal to the positive control citral also degenerated more quickly in thiacloprid exposed bees over the short term. The only long-term effect of pesticide exposure was a decrease in responsiveness to methyl salicylate in Thiacloprid exposed bees. Imidacloprid exposure induced no effects on antennal responses. The study also obserbed season-related differences in antennal responses to several VOCs and the alarm pheromone 2-heptanone. The authors conclude that their observation of volatile-specific chanmges in antennal responses may contribute to previously observed changes in the behaviour of neonicotinoid-exposed bees.
422.answer_rev2: The authors demonstrate that chronic exposure to neonics can alter the sensitivity of honey bee antennae to common VOCs, but that this isn't uniform. Thiacloprid increased response to several VOCs and common pheromones, but was primarily concentrated to short-term effects, whereas imidacloprid had no significant impact. Seasonal variation also contributed to reception. Concentration of short-term effects therefore provides hope for the recovery of honey bee populations

423.answer_llm: The paper underscores the importance of understanding the multifaceted effects of neonicotinoids on honeybee health, revealing both immediate and long-term consequences that can weaken colonies. It also emphasizes the role of genetic susceptibility in honeybees, which is vital for future research and conservation efforts in the field.
423.answer_rev1: The study did not find increased winter losses associated with neonicotinoid exposure, however there were negative short-term effects, including reduced pollen collection and honey production,. and long-term impacts (lower numbers of adult bees, pupae, eggs and larvae) on colony performance and queen fate, which the authors conclude means that neonicotinoids may affect colony weakening in complex ways. The study also found differences between the two strains of bees, with the long-term effects of pesticide exposure on adult numbers in the following spring being much stronger for strain B than strain A, suggesting that there may be a genetic componenet to neonicotinoid susceptibility that should be considered in future.

427.answer_llm: The discussion underscores the importance of accurately assessing the impact of insecticides on pollinators, particularly in realistic field conditions, to inform conservation efforts and policy-making.

427.answer_rev2: The study was one of the few to investigate the effects of pesticide exposure under field settings. The authors observed subtle changes to patterns of foraging activity and pollen loads in clothianidin exposed colonies. However there were more pronounced effects observed in the colony census data with fewer adult workers and sexuals produced by clothianidin exposed colonies after five weeks. There was no diofference in colony weight gain, nor on the number of brood indivbiduals however. The authors suggest that their field based approach, are important and currently under utilised for risk assessment, and that incorporating behavioural measures is important since this may provide insights into changes in pollinator numbers or reduction in fitness, as well as insights into effects on ecosystem services such as pollination.

429.answer_llm: The discussion in the paper highlights the importance of bees in providing pollination services for crops and wild plants, noting that wild bees can be more effective than honey bees. 429.answer_rev1: The study found that cypermethrin and imidacloprid reduced bee visits to sunflowers for up to two days post-exposure, firpronil only on the day of spraying, and indoxabarb induced a reduction in visits for four days post-spraying. No effects were observed for the other chemicals and control (water treatment). The majority of the findings are corroborated by existing literature, but there was a difference between the findings of the current study and those of Karise et al. (2007) who did not observe an effect of cypermethrin on honeybee visitation to Brassicas, and Rieth and Levin who reported only a 24hour effect, compared to the 2-day effect reported here. The authors suggest these differences may be attributable to the variability in floral resources and doses used between studies. The significance of the specific findings of this study are not discussed by the authors

430.answer_rev1: The paper concludes that despite numerous contributors to bee declines, the negative effects of pesticides are widespread and the increase in neonicotinoid and pyrethroid use is a major driver of changes in occupancy across hundreds of wild bee species across the contiguous United States. Therefore the authors conclude that strategies to reduce pesticide use such as IPPM should be implemented to facilitate pollinator conservation.
430.answer_rev2: The authors conclude that recent changes in land use and pesticide administration (both associated with intensive agriculture) can cause declines in probability of up to 43.3% - but also that this differs hugely by species and overwhelmingly impacts native bee populations the most

Thus the authors conclude that toxicity is higher in disaccharides compared to monosaccharides, and that crops having high sucrose content in their nectars could help reduce mortality of bees.

The same concentration of flupyradifurone had no effects on syrup consumption or larval/pupal development, but as with imidacloprid it did affect the microbiota, downregulating carbohydrate metabolism and upregulating energy  metabolism. The authors conclude that while this newer pesticide may be safer than older chemicals, further investigation of the mechanisms of action are needed.

The authors conclude that this study provides important insights into the mechanism underlying the impact of neonicotinoids on pollinators, including higher-level processes such as pollination. They suggest that failing to consider the comboined effects may underestimate the harmful conseqeuences of pesticide use on pollinator performance and fitness.

657.answer_rev1: In standard LD50 laboratory tests, imidacloprid showed high oral toxicity to honeybees (Apis mellifera). However ﻿the residue levels of imidacloprid in nectar and pollen of seed-treated sunflower plants in the field was negligible. ﻿Chronic feeding experiments showed that even at the highest test concentration, imidacloprid showed no adverse effects on the development of the exposed bee colonies. The authors thus claim   that a sunflower seed dressing with imidacloprid poses no risk to honeybees.

658.answer_llm: The paper emphasizes the importance of understanding the effects of stereoisomeric pesticides like S-dinotefuran on honeybee social behavior, revealing how it influences feeding preferences and interactions that could accelerate pesticide transmission within colonies. This research is vital for assessing the ecological risks associated with neonicotinoid use.
658.answer_rev1: The authors found that honeybees exhibit a preference for consuming food containing S-dinotefuran, actively engage in trophallaxis with S-dinotefuran–consuming peers, and consequently acquire higher levels of S-dinotefuran compared with R-dinotefuran. In comparison to R-dinotefuran, S-dinotefuran stimulates honeybees to elevate their body temperature. The transcriptome also revealed significant enrichment in the thermogenesis pathway following S-dinotefuran treatment compared with R-dinotefuran treatment. Finally, most of the top 20 significantly enriched GO terms were associated with respiration, oxidoreductase activity, mitochondrial respiratory chain, mitochondrial ATP synthesis coupled electron transport, ATP synthesis coupled electron transport, and energy metabolism.

659.answer_rev1: This study demonstrated that: 1) honeybee workers in the hives located in neighborhood of a rice field, preferentially forage rice flowers during the flowering season; 2) many honeybee workers died in front of the hive entrance within 24 hours following the application (spray) of clothianidin; 3) after that, few dead worker were observed in front of the hive entrance; 4) neither a rapid drop in brood production nor colony collapse were detected. Neonicotinoid application within a rice field increased honeybee mortality immediately after its application, but the observed short-term effects do not always lead to collapse of a neighboring honeybee
659.answer_rev2: The paper found that honeybee workers in hives close to rice fields preferentially forage from rice flower. They conclude that clothianidin spraying of rice fields increases honeybee mortality 24 hours after spraying, but that hive brood weight and capped brood area did not significantly differ between hives placed at varying distances from the treated field. They concluse that clothianidin does not always lead to colony collapse.

662.answer_rev2: The authors suggest that their approach overcomes the bias of choosing phenotypes ahead of time but looking for how pesticides affect animal traits through changes in gene expression, and provides novel insights into the effects of field realistic neonicotinoid exposure on nurse and forage bee gene expression. They found that neonicotinoids differentially affected the neurogenomic state of foragers and nurses, where foragers experienced shifts in expression of genes involved in cognition and development and nurses experienced shifts in genes involved in metabolism, esuggesting that the two types of worker bee are affected in different ways by neonicotinoids. The fact that there was minimal overlap in the gene expression results compared to previous work, the authors suggest will help to reconcile contradictory results in the neonicotinoid literature, due to differences in cohorts of bees, but also different exposure parameters and caged vs field conditions.

663.answer_rev1: The main findings of the papers are that imidacloprid significantly affected honey production, total number of bees and activity of the immune-related enzyme phenoloxidase in forager bee extracts.  Apart from variables that were themselves components of colony strength (numbers of bees/brood cells), the only indicator that was both influenced by an insecticide and predictive of overwintering strength was the concentration of 10HDA in worker bee heads.﻿ Finally, the fact that most secondary endpoints influenced by the treatments later showed to be irrelevant for overwintering strength illustrates the great resilience of the honey bee colony.

664.answer_rev1:
The pesticide treatment reduced wild bee density, solitary bee nesting, and bumblebee colony growth and reproduction under field conditions﻿. Hence, such insecticidal usecan pose a substantial risk to wild bees in agricultural landscapes, and the contribution of pesticides to the global decline of wild bees may have been underestimated. The lack of a significant
response in honeybee colonies suggests that reported pesticide effects on honeybees cannot always be extrapolated to wild bees.

665.answer_rev1: Foraging activity of the bees did not appear to be impacted when neonicotinoids were applied as seed treatment neonicotinoid insecticides were present below the limits of quantification in pollen and nectar.Contrarily, foliar application of the neonicotinoides significantly reduced the foraging activity between 1 and 3 days after application and neonicotinoids were detected in leaf, pollen and nectar samples. 7 days after spraying, foraging activities went back to values comparable to control.
665.answer_rev2: The study found that when applied as a seed treatment, levels of pesticide residues in pollen and nectar samples were below quantifiable levels, whereas levels in foliar spray treated plants were higher. In line with this, they observed no effect of the seed treatment on honeybee foraging behaviour, whereas foliar sprays reduced foraging for 1-3 days post-application, but that this returned to normal levels after 7 days. Therefore the authors conclude that there is little short-term impact of neonicotinoid application on bee foraging activity, especially when applied as a seed treatment. The authors recommend that sprays should not be used during flowering stages.

666.answer_rev1: The paper found that Bt only caused toxicity at extremely high concentrations and therefore conclude it does not pose a risk to bumblebees. Some of the pesticides tested- sulfoxaflor, deltamethrin and esfenvalerate were found to be more toxic than one of the neonicotinoids banned for outdoor use in the EU, which the authors conclude is concerning since these are likely to replace the banned pesticides and may have an impact on bee populations.
666.answer_rev2: The results obtained with both LC50 and LD50 reveal that the acute toxicity levels of the different insecticides that caused mortality to bumblebees followed the following sequence: imidacloprid > sulfoxaflor > deltamethrin > esfenvalerate > thiacloprid. Finally, the microbial insecticide formulated from insecticidal toxins of B. thuringiensis showed no significant toxicity to this species.

668.answer_llm: The paper emphasizes the importance of accurate risk assessments in the field of agrochemicals, particularly emphasizing the need to use queenright colonies instead of microcolonies for evaluating the effects of pesticides like thiacloprid on pollinators. 668.answer_rev1: The study compared different assessment methods for neonicotinoids- namely lab experiments with microcolonies vs queenright colonies and field experiments with queenright colonies. They found that the results with microcolonies contradicted the results with queenright colonies, and that different effects were found during short vs. long term experiments highlighting the need for long term experimnets in risk assessments and the potential for underestimating risk when using microcolonies. The effects of thiacloprid on the fitness of queenright colonies was also confirmed by the field experiment, and the negative effects of acetamiprid were only apparent under field conditions. Thus the authors conclude that field realistic set ups and assessment of gyne production are critical for assessing the sublethal effects of pesticides on bees.
668.answer_rev2: The main finding of the study is that the results from microcolonies contradict results from queenright colonies. While thiacloprid negatively impacted gyne production in queenright colonies, it had a positive effect on microcolony size. The negative effect of thiacloprid on colony fitness was confirmed under field conditions, where thiacloprid affected the production of reproductives, colony weight gain, worker weight, and foraging behaviour. For acetamiprid, a negative trend on colony fitness could only be shown in a field setup.

671.answer_rev2:
This study showed that when ACT or DEL  were applied 24 h before or during learning, that they did not affect learning sessions but they affected memory retrival. In particular, when drugs were applied 24 h before learning sessions, ACT appeared more effective than DEL at 24 h after learning session, however, the ACT effect occurred at a higher dose (100 ng/bee) whereas DEL impaired retrieval performance at a lower dose (10 ng/bee). 
When drugs were applied during learning sessions, they both strongly impaired retrieval of the PER at 24 h after learning. ACT was the only one able to impair retrieval at a lower dose.
